conversation.content: Have you ever done anything [cough] really dangerous? Like actually life-threatening?
Oh man, so, there was this time in Peru when I, you know, completely misjudged a river crossing— the locals were basically screaming at me to stop but I was too stubborn to listen.
Wait, umm, you crossed anyway? That's, I mean, either brave or really stupid.
Honestly, it was definitely more stupid than brave— like, the current knocked me off my feet immediately and I was, er, basically pinballing between rocks for what felt like forever.
Did you think you were [child-like] going to die?
For about thirty seconds, absolutely. But then this weird calm kicked in and my body just took over— grabbed a branch, pulled myself out, threw up river water for ten minutes.
That's [mumbling] insane. Why would you keep traveling after that?
Because, well, getting knocked around taught me more about respecting nature than, you know, any guidebook ever could— plus, um, the adrenaline aftermath was honestly incredible.
I could [upset] never do that. I'd be traumatized forever, probably never leave my house again.
Hey, that's totally valid. Not everyone processes fear the same way— for me, near-misses make me feel more alive, but my sister won't even go camping after a bad thunderstorm experience.
Your family must [shaky voice] worry about you constantly.
Oh god, actually, my mom has this whole ritual now where she, like, lights candles whenever I travel— err, she pretends it's just for ambiance but I know better.
Do you ever, um, feel guilty about putting them through that? I mean, the stress must be awful.
Sometimes, yeah. But they also love hearing the stories afterward— my dad keeps this scrapbook of all my adventures, newspaper clippings and photos and everything.
What's the scariest animal you've, well, encountered? Like, the thing is, I'm terrified of basically everything with teeth.
Probably the bull shark in [bitter] Fiji that, uhh, decided my kayak looked interesting— honestly, I still get nightmares about those dead eyes just, you know, circling and circling.
But you still [extremely happy] go in the ocean? That's incredible!
Yeah, though now I, er, definitely check local shark reports first— I mean, I'm adventurous, not suicidal, and there's really no shame in being cautiously reckless.
Cautiously reckless? That's, hmm, kind of an oxymoron, isn't it? Actually, I guess that perfectly describes you.
Exactly! It's about, well, calculating risks while still saying yes to experiences— like, anyway, you can be smart about being stupid, if that makes any sense at all.
